SummaryOfEvents: The Pomerania had a ship on her starboard side. Both ships were aware of one another. The Pomerania Officer of Watch (OOW) accepted a closest point of approach (CPA) of 0,3 M and he occupied himself with other matters, in spite of the fact that the lookout tried to call his attention several times to the approaching situation. On board the Rio Grande the OOW unsuccessfully tried to call the Pomerania and then tried to take an evasive action. None of these manoeuvres however was made until the last minute. The two vessels collided in such way that the Pomerania run into the port side of the Rio Grande

ON JANUARY 28TH,  2005 AT ABOUT 15:15 HRS, A FIRE OCCURRED IN THE ENGINE ROOM ON BOARD  M/N "MOBY LOVE", WHICH WAS AT BERTH IN PIOMBINO. INVESTIGATIONS REVEALED THAT THE FIRE  STARTED BECAUSE THERE WAS AN OVER FLOW OF DIESEL FROM THE GASOLINE HEATER, POSITIONED NEXT TO THE MAIN PROPULSION ENGINE.

During departure from St.Thomas on January 27, 2005, a crew member got trapped while 
attempting to pass through a watertight door in a crew cabin area. The door was in remote 
closing mode and closed on his back so that the crew member became compressed against the 
door frame and was unable to breathe. Several other crewmembers rushed to his rescue but 
were unable to operate the door handle, as the trapped crew member’s shoulder blocked the 
movement of the handle. Engineers soon arrived to assist and managed to free the crew 
member by breaking the power supply to the hydraulic pump and unscrewing a pipe joint to 
bleed off the pressure. The crew member was freed after 8 – 10 minutes. The medical team 
attempted resuscitation without success.

InitialEvent: Accidents with life-saving appliances + Man overboard
SummaryOfEvents:
At about 0400 on 27 January 2005, a crew member on board the French Antarctic support vessel L'ASTROLABE went missing prior to going on watch.  At the time, the vessel was in the Southern Ocean, 234 nautical miles south of the Tasmanian port of Hobart. After a search of the vessel and sea, the crew member was found in the ocean near the position of the vessel at the time he was last seen on board.  When found, he was deceased.
In the subsequent operation to recover the deceased crew member, the second engineer suffered a severe laceration to his right hand, almost severing the thumb, when it became caught between the lifeboat fall block and the hook assembly on the after end of the lifeboat.

While on passage across the Pacific from Vancouver to Hakodate, Explorer encountered severe weather over several days during which superficial damage to deck fittings occurred and difficulties were experienced in securing lifeboats, tenders and gangways. On 27 January 2005, while making a speed of 7 knots, the ship was struck by two large waves in succession. Water was slow to clear from the foredeck and the second wave struck the bridge front, breaking a while house window near the centreline of the ship. A large quantity of water entered the bridge and caused severe water and physical damage to the control console. The main engines stopped and the ship drifted beam on to the weather.

 After overcoming difficulties in starting the main engines on local engine room control, the ship regained steerage way and altered course to place the wind and seas astern. The ship then diverted to Hawaii where essential repairs were made

InitialEvent: OTHER - flooding and sinking (sea water ingress through outboard shipside valve)
SummaryOfEvents:
The fishing vessel PAULA arrived in the Norwegian port of Selje, Maloy on the evening of 23rd January 2005 to discharge her catch of 270 tonnes of mackerel.
Prior to commencing discharge of cargo routine maintenance was carried out on the vessel's sea water system on the morning of 24th January 2005.
During this maintenance operation seawater entered the engine room through the port seawater suction strainer.
Efforts to halt the ingress of water proved unsuccessful and the engine room and adjacent spaces flooded causing the vessel to partially sink alongside the quay.
All persons escaped safely to the quayside without injury.  There was minimal pollution caused.

At about 0408 on 23 january 2005, just south of the Grimsby Middle bank in the Humber estuary on the east coast of the UK, the outbound UK flag Amenity collided with the in-bound norwegian flagged Tor Dania. Both vessels suffered extensive damage, but were able to berth without assistance before being withdrawn from service for repairs.There were no injuries or pollution.

The vessel touched the Moellegrund in Kerteminde Bay and got an approximately 40 meters long fracture in the bottom, and fuel tanks #3 ans #4 were opened to the sea with the result of the spillage of approximately 5 m3 light fuel oil on its way north in the Great Belt.

ALGA was on a voyage from Odense to Copenhagen loaded with 1016 MT steel scrap. After the passage of Fyns Hoved it was the intention to continue on a northerly course west of Bolsaks. The crew member, alone on the bridge, could not see the bouy and he set the propeller in neutral. Immediatly after the vessel foundered at Bolsaks shoal at 1.3 meters dept of water. Following a lightering of the tanks the ship was deemed "a total loss".

Some 20 minutes after casting off from Saint-Guénolé a fire was discovered in the engine room.  Attempts to extinguish the fire were unsuccessful and the crew of five abandonned ship and were rescued.  ALCOR on fire drifted and ran onto nearby reefs.

Location: 1 nautical Mile North of Erris Head, Co Mayo.
SummaryOfEvents:
At approximately midnight on Thursday 17 February 2005, the skipper of the yacht “Rondo” and his son left Sligo bound for Dublin in their 9-meter “Gibsea” class yacht. 
In view of the North Westerly weather conditions it was decided at the time to go south about with the option of sheltering at various locations along the way.

The following day, 18 February 2005 at approximately 19:00 hours when in a position about one nautical mile north West of “Erris Head” Co. Mayo, the Skipper was washed overboard. A search and rescue mission got underway resulting in the safe rescue of his son, the second crew member. At approximately 21:30 hours that evening, the skipper remained missing.

At approximately 10:00 hours on the morning of 19 February 2005 the body of the skipper was recovered from the sea by search and rescue units and taken to Mayo General Hospital for autopsy.

While on passage from Grand Turk to Port Everglades, a fire developed in the diesel generator room resulting in a loss of main electrical power and shut down of the main engines.  Emergency power was supplied by the emergency generator which started automatically and the fire was rapidly extinguished by the crew.  Propulsion and electrical power was restored and the vessel resumed passage to port, where the fire was investigated.  There were no injuries to any persons.

On 16th January 2005 at 17.10 hours LT  the ship was heading North in the Suez Canal, when it was found that the internal the stern tube bearing was damaged. The ship anchored and was later taken in tow to be repaired.

On 14th January 2005 the M/V ISOLA AZZURRA, which had sailed from Lavera, in France, arrived at Sarroch terminal for discharging operations.  About 7000 litres of gasoil were discharged, and in the evening the vessel left Sarroch terminal for the port of Livorno. During navigation an explosion occurrred in the ventilators in the forcastle, which left two crew members dead. A casualty investigation team from the local PSC office carried out an initial inspection on board, and found that the explosion was due to human modification of the non-return valve in the cargo tank's ventilation line. Explosive gas coming from cargo tank no. 6 entered the ventilator room and caused the explosion when the electrical switch in the room was turned on by a crew member, who died instantly.  Another crew member died as a result of the explosion.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Ship rendered unfit to proceed

Location: Approach channel to port of Newhaven, England
SummaryOfEvents:
At 1946 UTC on 11 January 2005, the Italian registered ro-ro passenger ferry SARDINIA VERA ran aground in the approach channel to the port of Newhaven on the south coast of England.  The position of the grounding was in the charted deep water channel about 20 metres to starboard of the centreline, a position where the Master should have been able to expect sufficient depth of water to navigate safely.  The vessel re-floated at 2131 UTC with the rising tide and proceeded to sea stern first, where safety checks were completed before re-entering harbour to berth safely at 2223 UTC.  There were no injuries or pollution, and the vessel did not sustain any damage.
The grounding on 11 January brought to 13 the number of reportable accidents involving the two Transmanche Ferries vessels in the port of Newhaven in less than 4 years.  Ten of the accidents and incidents were groundings or near groundings, and three were collisions and contacts, one involving the other ferry DIEPPE.  As a consequence, MAIB took the opportunity to probe more deeply the management of safety at Newhaven as it pertained to the Newhaven-Dieppe ferry operation.

On 9th January 2005 at 13.50 hours LT a collision occurred between the fishing vessel VOLHARDING HD 36 and the general cargo ship SANDETTIE in a traffic seperation scheme in the North Sea. The collision was due to insufficient look out by both ships.

On 8th January 2005 the M/V SCHIEBORG ran into bad weather and sustained  damage to vessel and cargo (containers, SECU's) on deck. Due to heavy water on deck, the damaged deck cargo Calcium Carbide (IMO 4.3) caught fire at approximately 14.00 hours LT.  Attempts to extinguish the fire failed due to weather/ wind/ rolling vessel. In addition there was steering gear failure. The vessel sent an SOS to Lyngby Radio. The vessel dropped anchor, but the helicopter that came to assist could not take people from board, due to the weather circumstances (around 19.00 hrs). The crew left the vessel by lifeboat, and were picked up by supply vessel's  fast rescue boat, by jumping one by one into the water (9 January 2005 at around 01.50 hours LT).

On 29th December 2004 at 19.05 hours LT, the Isle of Mull was approaching the link span at Oban. An incomplete hand over of controls from the centre console to the starboard bridge wing console resulted in one main engine still going ahead when astern thrust was applied. Attempts were made to rectify the situation but there was not enough time and the vessel glanced off a moored ferry before her bow collided with the pier. There were no passengers onboard at the time. The bow door visor was damaged and watertight integrity above the waterline was breached. The ship had a temporary repair made to the bow to allow it to sail to a dockyard on the Clyde for repair.

Location: Gulf of Peter the Great, Sea of Japan

SummaryOfEvents: On 23.12.2004 the ship left Bayonne port in Frace and started to proceed in ballast to the Baltic Sea. On 25.12.2004 at 03.20 oncoming wave hit the ship's hull, resulting in strong vibration of the ship. Ship's speed was reduced and her course was altered. The shipowner and Ushant VTS were informed and permission was requested to go to anchorage in Douarnenez Bay. A survey established that one propeller blade was missing. On 26.12.2004 the towing of the ship to Brest was started. On 27.12.2004 diver survey was conducted to establish damages in detail.

On 21st December 2004 the general cargo ship POOLGRACHT was in the north Atlantic en route from Three Rivers, Canada, to Australia. At 02.40 hours LT, due to the stowage and constitution of Ammonium Nitrate in big bags, the vessel  listed 25-30 degrees. She later sailed to Providence USA where her cargo was discharged. Possible causes: beads of different sizes caused settlement after stowage on board, and were possibly crushed due to excessive temperature changes.

Location: OPEN SEA - on the way to Naples
SummaryOfEvents: AT 23.00 HOURS LT ON 18TH DECEMBER 2004 THE M/V VINCENZO FLORIO WAS EN ROUTE FROM PALERMO TO NAPLES WHEN IT EXPERIENCED A BLACK OUT THAT CAUSED THE MAIN ENGINES TO BE TURNED OFF.  AT 00:40 A FIRE IN THE RO-RO CARGO WAS DETECTED, WHICH WAS EXTINGUISHED BY 03.4O HOURS LT. THE ENGINES WERE RE-STARTED AND THE SHIP STEERED TOWARDS PALERMO WHERE SHE ARRIVED AND MOORED AT 07:50 HOURS LT ON 19TH DECEMBER 2004. SHE HAD SUSTAINED A HEELING ON THE LEFT SIDE OF ALMOST 10/12 DEGREES,  CAUSED BY THE WATER USED TO EXTINGUISH THE FIRE.

Location: 15 miles off Paihai, Bay of Islands

SummaryOfEvents:
On 16 December 2004 at about 15:06h the harbour tug JULIUS capsized on the river Elbe at river km 694.5 near the Elbehafen port.  The tug JULIUS belonged to a tug/barge system consisting of the tug PARAT and the pontoon E3505. The tug JULIUS was to be used as a steering/braking tug and pushed its post against the stern of the pontoon E3505.
As a consequence of unforeseeable circumstances the post swung out of the direction of travel to port.  The port mooring line leading from the stern of the tug to the pontoon became caught beneath the wheelhouse roof and the tug capsized over its starboard side.  After the two aft mooring lines were ruptured, the tug sank to the bottom of the river Elbe.
Of the two crew members on board at the time of the accident, the trainee ship's mechanic was recovered with minor injuries.  Despite search measures immediately initiated, it was not possible to find the Master.
A corpse that had drifted into the outer harbour of the New Lock in Brunsbüttel on 28 April 2005 was identified as the missing Master. The post mortem examination revealed "death due to drowning or hyporthemia" as cause of death.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: Sea of Iyo, 20kms W.N.W. of Nagahama
SummaryOfEvents:
Explosions occurred during tank cleaning operations.
This resulted in serious damage, the tanks were flooded and 3 crew members who were engaged in operations on deck were subsequently reported missing.
Eventually the fire was brought under control but the vessel developed a serious list and sank.
Consequences1: Total loss of the ship,Loss of life

SummaryOfEvents: On 11th December 2004 the tanker British Enterprise was fully laden with a cargo of crude oil and drawing a maximum draught of 11.17m. The vessel anchored in a designated anchorage after transitting the outbound Istanbul Straits in order to load bunker fuel. Upon completion the vessel was turned around after heaving up the anchor, in order to depart from the port, and ran aground at 14.05 hours LT in the anchorage where the minimum charted depth was 13 metres. The vessel was subsequently refloated 5 days later at 15.10 hours LT on 16th  December after offloading some cargo and ballast water. The vessel sailed from the port on 23rd December 2004.

SOLASStatus: BUNGA MAS LAPAN: Unknown/unspecified, KYUSHO MARU No. 21: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
In Kanmon Passage off Moji Saki, the stem of the Bunga Mas Lapan (8,957
gross tons; hereinafter called “Bunga”), a Malaysian-registered vessel, struck into the
starboard midship section of a Japanese-flag ship, Kyusho Maru No. 21 (999 gross
tons; hereinafter called “Kyusho Maru”), at 1915 hours on December 10, 2004, at a
position 012º, 130 meters from Moji-saki Lighthouse, at an angle of 35º leading
forward on the latter.
As a result of the collision, the Kyusho Maru suffered damage, including a hole
in the shell plating in the starboard midship section, and the Bunga a hole in the
bulbous bow on the port side and scraping damage on the shell plating in the port bow
section; both vessels were repaired thereafter.

On 9th December 2004 the ship was proceeding north in route T in the Great Belt. The draft was 12.8 meters. After a turn to a northerly course the ship was proceeding on the wrong side of the route. The ship then crossed the route but continued out of the route at Egholm Flak. Six minutes before the grounding the ship was contacted by VTS Great Belt and warned, but at 09.05 hours LT the vessel grounded before it was able to return to the route.

Location: Off Skan Bay, Unalaska Island (Aleutian Islands)

SOLASStatus: Hyundai Advance: Unknown/unspecified, HYUNDAI ADVANCE: Unknown/unspecified, MSC Ilona: Unknown/unspecified, MSC ILONA: SOLAS
SummaryOfEvents: On 7 December 2004 the MSC ILONA and HYUNDAI ADVANCE collided.  Both vessels remained floating.  HYUNDAI  ADVANCE was able to continue to Singapore for repairs but MSC ILONA had to remain anchored initially at the scene of the accident and later in a position allocated by the authorities.  1283 tonnes of heavy oil flowed into the open sea causing pollution. After extensive cleaning and emergency repair measures had been carried out MSC ILONA was able to make her way to Singapore.

The HANYANG GAS was on passage from Jeju on 5 December 2004 to Ulsan in Korea.  At 1450 a fire broke out in the crew accommodation 6.18 miles away from the west breakwater of Jeju. The accommodation space and engine room were completely destroyed by the fire and three crew members died.
Consequences1: Ship rendered unfit to proceed,Loss of life

SummaryOfEvents: At midnight on 5th December 2004 the ship made contact with a light house during approach to Aalborg. Ingress of water resulted in list. Rescue vessels with pump assistance were sent to the area. The ship managed to get into the port Hals.

Location: 230 miles S.W. of Kauai, Hawaiian Islands
159 nm S.S.E. of Cape Cod, Massachusetts
South east end of Holyhead breakwater
SummaryOfEvents: At 09:40 (UTC) on 1 December 2004, the Cayman Islands registered product tanker Stolt Tern ran off the south eastern end of the breakwater in Holyhead, following passage from Immingham. The ship was re-floated the same morning and proceeded to an alongside berth. The ship was carrying 4000 tonnes of gas oil. However despite damage to the vessel, including spite to her hull, there was no pollution.

Location: Approx. 70 miles S.S.W. of Bear Island
East-West traffic lane of TSS Les Casquets
SummaryOfEvents: The fishing vessel l'ALIZEE III collided with the Antigua and Barbuda registered general cargo SUSANNA.  The general cargo suffered only minor damage and continued its voyage. The fishing vessel was able to return to port without assistance but the damage sustained necessitated some urgent repairs.

The Ship Polo M, flying Bahamas flag, was riding at anchor in the road off Slite, Gotland, Sweden on the November 2004 at 19:50. The ship was anchored  by the port side anchor with 7 shackles (192 m) of chain in the sea.

In the evening loading of cement from the ship Sunnanvik started. Up till 22 November at 17:00 
Sunnanvik had made three trips between Slite and Polo M. The loading was then suspended due to the strong wind. 

On 23 November between 06:00 and 07:30 Polo M was dragging on two occasions, which was noted neither by the master nor the 3rd officer who are both said to have been on the bridge. After that the ship was on the whole lying still until 08:00 when the anchor started to drag agin.
Polo M. grounded on 23 November at about 08:35 in position approximately 58° 38’.4 N, 018° 48’.6 E.

On 22 November 2004, the 4955GT Maltese registered general cargo ship Ileksa and the UK registered container ship Cepheus J were transiting the Kattegat off the Danish coast.  Both vessels were following the recommended route ‘T’ on a south-easterly course.  At about 0519 UTC, the two ships collided, with the Cepheus J’s bow striking the stern of Ileksa.  The impact caused severe damage to Ileksa’s stern and holed the Cepheus J above the waterline.

Both vessels were able to resume their voyages and there were no injuries and pollution as a result of this accident.

Location: 35 miles N.W. of Ullung Island, Sea of Japan

SOLASStatus: EASTERN CHALLENGER: Unknown/unspecified, RITHI BHUM: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents: The EASTERN CHALLENGER left Kualo, Vietnam on 11 November 2004 carrying a cargo of 6100 tons of ore bound for Onahama, Japan.  The RITHI BHUM left Hong Kong on 13 November 2004 and was heading for Shanghai.  Later that evening RITHI BHUM detected EASTERN CHALLENGER running ahead on her radar screen.  RITHI BHUM was detected by EASTERN CHALLENGER on her radar.  RITHI BHUM overtook EASTERN CHALLENGER on the starboard side and at the same time had to avoid another vessel.  She then collided with EASTERN CHALLENGER.  Due to flooding the crew of EASTERN CHALLENGER left the vessel and was picked up by RITHI BHUM who returned to Hong Kong.  EASTERN CHALLENGER sank later.

At 20:10 on 12 November 2004, MARINE OSAKA arrived at the outer anchorage in Ishikari harbour, southwest of Hokkaido, Japan, and anchored in position 296°(T), 0.95 miles from the breakwater entrance light in ballast condition with 6 shackles of starboard anchor chain.  While she was waiting for the berthing schedule, her anchor began to drag under strong wind and storm weather conditions.  The vessel hove up the anchor and tried to move to the open sea, but she drifted towards the breakwater in spite of every effort.  Her stern made contact with the tetrapod of the breakwater first, and then she was parallel to the breakwater where she grounded at 01:49 on 13 November 2004.  
As a result, the hull was broken into three pieces and 7 out of the 16 crew members died.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: 20 miles E. of Saint Vincent & the Grenadines

SummaryOfEvents:
A collision occurred between the general cargo ship ARKLOW SKY and the fishing vessel MARIE GALANTE 1 whilst the latter was busy hauling her trawl gear. As a result of the collision, MARIE GALANTE 1 suffered some serious damage, her engines stopped, and 2 crew members were injured.
Under escort from another fishing vessel, MARIE GALANTE 1 managed to return to port under her own power.
The damage caused necessitated repairs in a shipyard which took several months to complete.

SummaryOfEvents: On the morning of 06 November 2004, the tug Manson, with crew of two, was on passage between New Westminster, British Columbia, on the Fraser River and Beale Cove, Texada Island, British Columbia, The Manson had two barges in tow: the crane barge McKenzie and the deck barge M.B.D.32. During the transit through the Strait of Georgia, the couplers connecting the M.B.D 32 to the stern of tern of the McKenzie parted. The Manson, with the McKenzie in tow, attempted to recover the M.B.D 32 but experienced steering difficulties during the process. The Manson capsized and sank with the loss of both crew members: a deckhand and the maser. Both barges were subsequently recovered; the Manson has not been located.
Consequences1: Loss of life,Total loss of the ship

Location: North Sea off the coast of Norway
InitialEvent: Hull failure / failure of watertight doors / ports, etc.
SummaryOfEvents: The vessel was fishing 65 nm west of Bergen. Alle crewmembers were working on the shelterdeck. The engine for the light stopped. They observed water ingress into the engine room. Assistance was called and they started a transportable diesel pump. According to the skipper it looked as the level of water in the engine room was getting lower. He called off the assistance. Suddently the vessel heeled over to port and they observed water in the hole. The crew went into the liferaft and the vessel sank shortly after.

SOLASStatus: DORTHE DALSOE: Unknown/unspecified, SCOT EXPLORER: Unknown/unspecified
SummaryOfEvents:
On 2nd November 2004, DORTHE DALSOE which was en route to homeport, collided with SCOT EXPLORER en route south in Route T. DORTH DALSOE's bow hit the port bow of SCOT EXPLORER. The DORTHE DALSOE sustained a leak in the fore ship and received pump assistance from other vessels which also brought her to port. SCOT EXPLORER only sustained scratches and could continue her voyage.
The two fishermen in DORTHE DALSO had been cleaning fish on deck, and there was no one in the wheel house. The master was alone on the bridge on the SCOT EXPLORER. Both vessels had detected the presence of the other by radar in good time.

Location: Grangemouth Docks, Firth of Forth, Scotland
SummaryOfEvents:
At about 18h23 UTC, the Isle of Man registered tanker BORDER HEATHER suffered an explosion and fire in her forecastle while in Grangemouth.  Significant damage was caused to the vessel's structure and systems but no-one was injured and there was no pollution.
The explosion happened after the ship loaded a volatile cargo of motor spirit (ultra low sulphur petrol or ULSP), some of which migrated into the forward space, housing the gas freeing fans, from the interconnected cargo and gas freeing systems.  A spectacle plate between theses sytems had not been fitted in the blanked position, the associated isolating valves had not been closed and a non-return valve leaked.
Motor spirit and vapour then drained into the spaces beneath the gas freeing room through the scuppers and an open hatch.  Once in the lowest space, the bow thruster room, vapour ignited by electrical equipment not intended for use in an explosive atmosphere.
The fire was tackled by the vessel's crew and finally extinguished by shore-based firefighters about 40 minutes after ignition.

AT 11.30 LT ON OCTOBER 30TH 2004 DURING THE VOYAGE FROM MESSINA STRAIT TO RAVENNA, THE VESSEL WAS STRANDED DUE TO DAMAGE TO THE MAIN ENGINE. AT 16:00 LT A LOCAL TUG HELPED TO GET THE SHIP AFLOAT. THE VESSEL THEN, UNDER ITS OWN PROPULSION, PROCEEDED TO AUGUSTA PORT WITH A TUG IN ASSISTANCE.

Location: Tahsish Inlet, Kyuquot Sound, British columbia
SummaryOfEvents: During the afternoon of 29 October 2004, the commercial fishing ship Prospect Point, with a crew of five on board, was fishing for sardines, in Kyuquot Sound, off the west coast of Vancouver Island, British Columbia. After pursing in the net, while the crew was in the process of preparing to haul in the catch of sardines, the ship heeled to starboard and capsized, forcing all the crew members into the water. The crew members were recovered and landed on board a coastal freighter anchored in the vicinity, the ship was subsequently recovered and towed to steveston, British Columbia. No injury was reported

MSC EYRA was southbound in the Great Belt on a voyage to Riga.

BERGITTA was northbound in the Great Belt on a voyage to Rotterdam with a cargo of 100,000 tons of crude oil. On board BERGITTA were two pilots, who should assist the ship trough Danish waters until the Skaw.

At about 2200 hours on the 24th of October 2004 both ships were heading towards the Agersoe Flak area.

Both ships had reported to VTS Great Belt and were within the VTS area.

There had been changeable visibility in the area. Before and in the connection with the collision the visibility was restricted – according to the involved persons a visibility of 0.5 – 0.8 nautical miles. 

On the ships the bridge teams became aware of each other’s presents on the radar and it was ascertained that the ships were going to meet each other in the area off Agersoe Flak.
Initially it was MSC EYRA´s intention to pass ahead of BERGITTA and continue southward via route-H.

The pilot on BERGITTA called MSC EYRA on VHF channel 16, when MSC EYRA was in the area off Vengeancegrund L/H. On VHF channel 6 it was agreed to pass port-to-port. This agreement was confirmed at a 2nd communication between the ships.         

The relative speed between the ships was very high especially when taking the prevailing circumstances and conditions into account. Thus the situation developed rapidly from the time when the communication was initiated and until at close-ship-situation developed off Agersoe Flak. 

The ships collided at approximately 2218 hours.

DURING NAVIGATION FROM LIPARI TO GIARDINI ON 23RD OCTOBER 2004 THE VESSEL'S ENGINE STOPPED AND THE VESSEL WENT ADRIFT FOR SEVEN HOURS.
AT 06:30 LT ON 24/10/2004 THE VESSEL WAS TOWED BY THE TUG BOAT "MILAE" TO MESSINA PORT, WHERE SHE ARRIVED AT 14:30H.

The Japanese-registered vessel Kaiwo Maru (gross tonnage 2,556 tons), while berthed at anchorage in Fushiki Toyama Port, Toyama Prefecture, was forced towards land by wind and waves under the impact of a typhoon, and ran aground on wave-absorbing blocks at the base of the breakwater 075° and 400 meters from Toyama East Breakwater Lighthouse, at 2247 hours on October 20th, 2004.
As a result, Kaiwo Maru sustained a number of dents and holes in her bottom shell plating, shipped water until seawater flooded the upper deck, and sank to the bottom. The hull was later refloated by a salvage company and repaired. Injuries of varying severity were suffered by 18 crew members, 8 cadets and 4 nautical trainees, respectively.

During the afternoon of 18 October 2004, in fine weather and good visibility, the passenger ship Balmoral grounded on Gagger Reef, Gower Peninsular. He ship was carrying 213 passengers and 19 crew on sightseeing excursion along the south Wales coast

THE EDGE OF LEFT CORNER OF THE STERN  HIT THE QUAY, CAUSING MINOR DAMAGE TO THE SAME AND TO THE PASSENGER'S RAMP.

Location: Off port Grosvenor, 110nm S. of Durban

SummaryOfEvents: AT 02:00 HOURS LT ON 15/10/2004, SHIP IRINIKOS, DURING MANOEUVRE TO APPROACH THE BRINDISI HARBOUR WAS SAILING WITH COURSE 310 IN COMPLIANCE WITH PORT REGULATIONS IN ORDER TO LEAVE ON THE SHIP'S PORT SIDE EXISTING SHOALS. AT 03:37 HOURS LT THE VESSEL CHANGED COURSE TO 300. AT 03:45 P.M. SHIP CHANGED COURSE AGAIN TO 289 AND INCREASED HER SPEED, LEAVING THE BUOY "TORRE CAVALLO" ON THE SHIP'S STARBOARD SIDE IN CONTRADICTION TO PORT REGULATIONS. AS A CONSEQUENCE, THE SHIP GROUNDED ON THE AFOREMENTIONED SHOALS AND SUFFERED DAMAGES RENDERING HER UNFIT TO PROCEED.

Location: Below Pultney Weir on River Avon at Bath
SummaryOfEvents:
On 14 October 2004, a converted ex-admiralty whaler, with nine passengers and s skipper onboard, flooded and capsized under Pulteney Weir on the River Avon at Bath.

The water flooded in, reducing the boat stability and causing her to capsize and tip the passengers and skipper into the water. Fortunately, the upturned ship stayed afloat, enabling those in the water to cling to the hull until the ship fetched up on the side of the river. The fire brigade launched a boat and was able to rescue them about 20 minutes after the incident. The passengers were traumatised, one had suffered a fractured wrist and others were affected by mild hypothermia.

The 4 seamen jumped into the sea. Two of them managed to reach the shore and to climb the cliff. The captain broke his leg whilst trying to rescue the third seaman who was found dead 3 days later.
The fishing vessel was wrecked.

SummaryOfEvents: At about 1525 on 7 October 2004 a fatal lifeboat incident occurred when the stern of the port lifeboat detached from the hook arrangement and later plunged from a height of about 16m into the sea during a lifeboat launching operation on the LOWLANDS GRACE. Two seamen died in the incident. Three other crewmembers sustained serious injuries. The fatal incident took place in good weather conditions.

The bridge team misjudged the situation during a turn in the DW route at Hatter in the great Belt. The turn was not sufficiently planned. There were unclear rudder commands. The masters attention was not sufficiently directed on the navigation. Pilot was not used. IMO's recommendation on use of pilot in the area was not followed.

In the late afternoon, on 29 September 2004, ARATERE gave a 10 mn warning call on VHF channels 16 and 19, of the vessel's entry into the Tory Channel Entrance Controlled Navigation Zone.
Subsequently, when the vessel passed East Head abeam to starboard, she was about 30m to starboard of her programmed track and the leading light line.  The visibility was good with North Westerly wind of 15 knots and a following spring flood tide.
ARATERE was operating in automatic track keeping mode, commonly referred to by Interislander personnel as 'ANTS TRACK'.  The Chief Officer had the con of the vessel and the Master was present on the bridge for the pilotage through the Tory Channel.  The vessel had a total complement of 292, comprising of 260 passengers and 32 crew.  Her draughts were 5.2m forward and 5.5m aft.
After passing East Head, ARATERE approached the programmed WOP (Wheel Over Position) which would take her onto the next programmed track.  The Chief Officer, who was monitoring the ANTS TRACK, noticed that the XTE (distance off track) was still to starboard of the leading light line, which the vessel was following to reach the programmed WOP.
At this stage, the Chief Officer informed the Master that the distance off track was 40m.  In response, the Master told the Chief Officer that he had seen the cross track error up to 85m with a flood tide.
By reference to the Conning Information Display Unit on the IBS, the Chief Officer continued to report an increase in the distance off track from 60 to 70, and then 80m.  ARATERE's speed was now 20.75knots and the vessel was 320m past her programmed WOP.
When the distance to starboard of Track C had reached 95m, the Master and the Chief Officer realised that on her current heading and speed, the vessel would shortly run aground in Whekenui Bay, Arapawa Island.
In an attempt to prevent this, the Master overrode the ANTS TRACK system by engaging the manual steering control and putting the helm to port.
ARATERE narrowly missed grounding in way of a rock situated to the south of Whekenui Bay.

On 25 September 2004 the general cargo ship MELLUM arrived at Thevenard, loaded cargo and on 28 September sailed for Melbourne.
At about 1217 the ship cleared Yatala Channel beacons one and two at a speed of about seven knots. Shortly thereafter the pilot disembarked as the ship approached the entrance beacon.  Once the pilot had disembarked the master ordered to steer a course of 222 degrees by gyro compass.
At 1233, the ship grounded with the entrance beacon bearing 0051/2 degree, at a range of 0.52 miles.
The master de-ballasted the ship and with the assistance of the pilot, who had reboarded, refloated the ship.  At 2309 the pilot reported that the ship was afloat.
At 1606 on 30 September, MELLUM weighed anchor and sailed for Melbourne after it had been checked for damage and seaworthiness.

Location: 8 miles North West of Skellig Island
SummaryOfEvents:
The fishing vessel SPAILPIN FANACH sailed from Castletownbere, Co. Cork on the 27th September 2004 with a crew of 3 persons on board.
Whilst engaged in fishing operations 11 nm West of the Skellig Islands on the morning of 28th September 2004 fire broke out in the engine room and rapidly engulfed the vessel.
The crew abandoned the vessel into a liferaft and were picked up by another fishing vessel.  No injuries were sustained by her crew members.
The SPAILPIN FANACH subsequently sank at position 51°46'N, 010°50.24'W, six hours later.
No pollution occurred.

At about 0900 on 27 September 2004 there was an improper release of 5,060 kg of carbon dioxide on board the YM PEOPLE 430 nautical miles east of Sri Lanka on its way from Singapore to the Suez Canal.  Four crewmembers inside the CO2 room suffocated and died.

SummaryOfEvents:
At 12:40 on 26 September 2004, the passenger ship Van Gogh recently departed from Gibraltar was outbound from the port of Tangier. The fully laden tanker Spetses was in bound for Algeciras oil refinery. They both collided in Gibraltar Bay in poor visibility. At a range of 100-150 metre, both vessels became visible to one another. The Master on Van Gogh ordered hard port helm and full astern on both engines and the one on Spetses ordered full astern on both engines. However their action failed to prevent a collision. Van Gogh’s bow struck the starboard side of Spetses. 
As a result of the collision Van Gogh sustained substantial bow and forward starboard side shell plate damage. Spetses sustained shell plate damage amidships on her starboard side. Fortunately there were no reported injuries on either ship.

SummaryOfEvents:
Just after 2300 on 14 September, after having caused a near accident earlier in the evening, FJORD ICE run aground south-east of the lighthouse Flintrännan NO.  
The grounding was preceded by the ship being positioned too far to port side in the fairway and when encountering another ship just before the grounding she turned even further to port and thus worsened the situation.
Relatively strong current may have influenced the situation.  The Master was alone on the bridge until just before the grounding, when the helmsman came to the bridge; no system with a designated lookout was applied on board.

The motor sailing yacht Inis Mil departed Kenmare, Ireland an the 6 September 2004 bound for Cherbourg, France, via St. Marys in the Scilly Isles.  After several failures within the yacht (the main pump, the second pump, the main cooling system), the crew were exhausted from physical effort and seasickness. On the evening of 8 September 2004 the ship was abandoned by the five person crew.
After 8 days in a six man liferaft the crew were rescue by the United Kingdom coastguard off the North Cornish Coast.

Due to storm winds and high waves associated with the approach of Typhoon No. 16 of 2004, the Vietnamese cargo ship VIHAN No. 5 dragged anchor while anchored in the southeastern bay of Yurano Hana in Ehime Prefecture. At 12:25 on August 30th, 2004 the ship ran aground on the rocks of the seashore 1,750m from Yurano Hana lighthouse. After running aground, the ship continued to be pushed further northwards by the current. Four crew members, in a panic, left the bridge and went down to the poop deck where they were swept away by waves and fell into the sea. One was killed and the other 3 are missing.
The ship suffered hull damage followed by flooding. Fuel spillage polluted the nearby sea area including some mother of pearl shell cultivating rafts.
The 16 crew members who remained on the ship were rescued.

During the approach to the port of Newhaven, the helmsman steered to the Right instead of steering to the Left despite the correct instructions being given by the Captain.  
The Captain realising the error made by the helmsman gave immediate orders for the helm to be put hard to starboard but the ship grounded in the West North-West of the Western jetty.
This caused some damage to the hull which necessitated repairs.

A fishing vessel sank after an explosion. The two crewmembers were killed. The vessel had the explosion on board because gas used for cooking leaked out and was ignited. The gas was probably ignited in the engine room, which was below the messroom. A fire followed the explosion and the vessel sank. The two crewmembers were probably killed at the time of the explosion.

The force of the striking caused injuries to nine passengers and one crew member, and the ship sustained hull damage on the port side forward.

Location: Bay of Bengal, 70-80 miles S. of Haldia

SummaryOfEvents:
A RO-RO (HSC) with 430 pax had left port and whilst about 8 miles from its destination the navigating officer noticed smoke on the bridge sited engine room camera monitor.

Whilst watching the camera the vapour surrounding one of the main engines burst into flames.  The chief engineer located on the bridge reduced engine speed and commenced the engine room shut down procedure.  The fire in the meantime was about to be fought by the electrician but the assistant engineer relieved him.  At this point the flames were seen to die down and it was reported out about 3 minutes after discovery.

The vessel's emergency plan was followed and the captain had the situation firmly under control throughout.

There were no injuries and damage was limited to minor smoke staining above the engine.

The cause of the fire was a failed low pressure fuel pipe which supplied the fuel injection pump.  The pipe failed because it was ill fitted and was strained; the engine vibration exacerbated this.  The pipe has been forwarded by the DPA for metallurgical examination.

Metallurgical report received on 8 Nov 04 and placed in file.  The report confirmed that the cause of the pipe failure was probably the poor fitting procedure.  Para 3.4 of the conclusion section states that; gouging was found on one side of the spill pipe, where the compression nut had been forced against the spill pipe tubing, and this was further evidence that the pipe had been subject to excessive forces whilst being fitted to the engine."

The report confirms that failure was due to fatigue

One man was thrown against the windlass and mooring machinery and suffered injuries from which he later died. Another sustained severe lacerations to one leg while the third man was unhurt.

Seaman fell overboard whilst the nets were shot away.

Location: Alongside the lay-by  berth at Runcorn
InitialEvent: accidental release of vinyl chloride monomer
SummaryOfEvents:
On 11th August 2004 the gas carrier Coral Acropora was alongside the EVC berth at Runcorn on the Manchester Ship Canal when there was an escape of part of her cargo of Vinyl chloride monomer (VCM). The vessel’s crew, the port agency representative, the cargo surveyor, two terminal
staff who had been connecting the manifold, two people on the berth and a number of members of the public were exposed to VCM as the resulting gas cloud drifted downwind.
The Health and Safety Laboratory (HSL), an executive agency of the Health and Safety Executive (HSE), modelled the release of VCM and found the principal consequent risk to have been that of flash fire within about 50 metres of the escape. Their calculations showed no credible hazard from toxicity.
At the time of the accident, she had been preparing to start to discharge her cargo into shore cargo tanks situated about 3 kilometres from the berth.

At  05:30 hours eastern daylight time on 11 August 2004, the container ship Canada Senator was  proceeding  down bound on the St. Lawrence River under the conduct of a pilot when the sailboat Mondisy, under power was sighted by the bridge team on board the Canada Senator about two nautical miles ahead the main channel. Because the pilot of the Canada Senator was in doubt about the intension of the Mondisy, warming signals were sounded on two occasions on the ship’s whistle to no avail.  Avoidance manoeuvres were carried out by the Canada Senator, but a collision ensued. 

As a result of the impact, the ferro-cement ship Mondisy sank almost instantly, two of the four persons on board the Mondisy were recovered from the water and survived with minor injuries and the other two persons lost their lives.

On 11th August 2004 the general cargo ship ONEGO MERCHANT ran aground after departing Ardalstangen Norway on her way to Kaliningrad, Russia. The new 2nd Officer had been suffering from fatigue, after a trip by bus from Poland to the ship and a full shift after joining. The captain also suffered from fatigue due to long working days. The pilot requested a rest after 4 hours of work, the 2nd officer was left alone on watch and fell asleep. There was no watch alarm, no look out, and the captain was not advised.

Initial attempts to pull the Horizon free were unsuccessful, and a lightering plan was adopted. Eleven days later, after having off-loaded 109 containers, the vessel was re-floated and sailed to the port of Sorel. No pollution was observed, and damage to the ship was minor.

On 9th July 2004 Lyngby Radio (LYRA) informed Rescue Centre Denmark that the Bulgarian bulk carrier PETIMATA OT RMS had gone aground in the Great Belt. The ship was detained by the Danish Maritime Authority. The grounding occurred at 02.21 hours LT. The 1st, the 2nd mate and the helmsman were on the bridge. The ship was steered by hand, and two radars were operating. The ARPA-radar was set up with waypoints, and there was GPS. PETIMATA OT RMS was northwards bound from the deepwater route. At the turning point at Agersoe Flak, a southbound ship, the ELLEN THERESA, which was going to continue its voyage in route H, met PETIMATA OT RMS. In order to avoid grounding, PETIMATA OT RMS had to turn hard to port immediately after having passed ELLEN THERESA. For unknown reasons the manoeuvre did not succeed. The master of PETIMATA OT RMS stated that ELLEN THERESA pressed him out of the route, but according to the VTS recordings, ELLEN THERESA was following the route. The bridge teams on both ships had observed the other ship visually and by radar in good time before they met at Agersoe Flak. The ships were communicating on VHF before the grounding. The draft of PETIMATA OT RMS was 10.50 meters. None of the ships had pilot on board. PETIMATA was afloat after lightering one week after the grounding.

On 4 July 2007 at 05:00 hours in the morning, the Northern Faith arrived at the container terminal in the port of Koper, Republic of Slovenia and moored with her container starboard side. 3 fore and 3 stern lines as well as 2 springs each were put out forward and aft.
At 16:30 hours, the wind grew increasingly more forceful until, within just a few minutes, it had reached 9 Bft. There was a high container stack behind the vessel’s superstructure. This area exposed to the wind led to the stern of the Northern Faith being pushed very rapidly away from the pier. The second Nautical Officer sent a watchman forward to check the lines there while he ran to the aft. Later the watchman was sent to the aft to help the second Nautical Officer. When he arrived at the aft manoeuvring station, he found the second Nautical Officer severely injured and lying on the floor. He informed the bridge by telephone about the incident. 
At 17:39 hours, the injured man was transported by pilot’s ship to the Pier where he was given into the charge of the ambulance. The ambulance took the second Nautical Officer to the hospital where they immediately carried out emergency to save his right leg. The right arm has to be removed.

Contact with the pierhead of the eastern jetty at Dieppe harbour.

On 6 July 2004, the ship accompanied by a tug sailed from Dieppe to Le Havre in order to carry out final repairs. 
The report from FRANCE (Flag and Coastal State) concludes that the human factor played a major role in this incident.

The two-member crew of the sailing yacht Allmin intended to round the island of Rügen. The day stretch on 29 June 2004 began in Seedorf, Rügen, and was scheduled to the end in Sassnitz. After the yacht ran against a stone wall lying under water off the südperd at about 12:00 hours and had been towed free from there by the daughter ship of the rescue cruiser Fritz Behrens,   it continued its voyage northwards. When the two sailors had not reached their home port as planned one week later, a search was began,. Initially it was unsuccessful, the yacht and its crew were missing.

On 21 July 2004 the body of the yacht owner was found in the area of  Prorer Wiek, and on 29 July 2004 that of the co-sailor off Polish coast.
On 26 November 2004, the wreck of SY Allmin  was brought to the surface  of the water by the fishing  cutter Crampas when  its was heaving in its net at position 54°27.787N and  013°49.354E, but salvage was unsuccessful.

On 23 Mars 2005 VWFS Deneb lifted Allmin and brought it  to Sassnitz

Shortly after 18h22 on 28 June 2004, the inland motor tanker ENA 2, designed to transport sulphuric acid, ran into the Parkhafen from the main Norderelbe navigation channel within the port of Hamburg in order to continue further to the Petroleumhafen.
At the same time, the container vessel PUDONG SENATOR departed from its berth at the Eurogate container terminal and was running out of the Waltershofer Hafen on its way towards Rotterdam.
The two vessels collided in the area where the Parkhafen opens into the Norderelbe.  PUDONG SENATOR survived the collision without any major damage and after approval from the VTS Hamburg ran into the Elbe navigation channel and continued its voyage downstream along the river Elbe.  Before Brunsbüttel it was checked by the Waterway Police officers from a boat from the water.  Since no further damage apart from paint abrasion could be seen, the vessel was allowed to continue the voyage to Rotterdam with the provision that it will be surveyed there by the Classification Society.
The special transport vessel ENA 2 carrying a cargo of sulphuric acid was damaged on its port side.  Parts of the outer plating in the foreship area were deformed, water flooded into the forward port wing tank.  In addition, the port Schottel drive in the aft area became inoperable as a result of the collision with PUDONG SENATOR.  However, ENA 2 initially remained floating, continued under its own power without losing cargo into the Petroleumhafen and tied up with a slight list to port at the intended berth.  The Waterway Police and two fireboats of the fire brigade hurried to the damaged vessel. 
The fire brigade tried in vain to keep ENA 2 afloat; its list to port increased further.  At about 19h05, ENA 2 capsized and floated keel upwards in the port basin.  Sulphuric acid now escaped.
In the following days, a salvage firm secured and subsequently uprighted ENA 2.
In the meantime, a large part of the cargo had found its way into the port water.  The rapid dilution of the acid there meant that the major environmental pollution initially feared did not materialise.

SummaryOfEvents: On 23rd June 2006, en voyage from Kawasaki, Tokyo Bay, course 200 and speed approx. 14 knots, JORGEN LAURITZEN (JL) observed SANDRA AZUL (SA) on the port bow at a distance of approx. 1 nautical mile at course 310. It appeared as if SA was not going to give way, so the engine on board JL was stopped and shortly after, the master ordered hard port. Location: In transit between Santos and Aratu
SummaryOfEvents: The ship was loaded with chemicals and was northbound in the South Atlantic. Good visibility, daylight, calm sea and wind force approximately 5-8 metres per second from West.  The ship had discharged various cargoes including Paraffinic Solvent in Santos (Brazil) and had departed for Aratu. After one hour of tank cleaning of tank 1CS having contained Paraffinic Solvent, the aft fixed cleaning machine had stopped to rotate. Preparations had started to replace this unit with a portable cleaning machine. The first explosion took place at 1435 hrs local time in tank 1CS, and forced the bulkhead, deck and tank top out. The tank hatch was struck open and deformed. Soon thereafter a second and weaker explosion occurred in an adjacent tank 1CP loaded with Ethanol, and was probably caused by the first. The ethanol that had surfaced on the deck caught fire on the port tank deck and the fire extended all the way to the deck house. One able seaman was hit by the tank hatch of tank 1CS when the tank exploded. He was found later on, badly burnt, just behind the hatch. The Boatswain, also badly burnt, managed to move aft, where he was taken care of by the ship’s crew. The officer in charge of the navigational watch immediately set off the ship’s general emergency alarm, and fire-fighting operations were started without delay by using the foam monitors on the tank deck. At 1505 HRS the fire on deck was extinguished. Distress alerts were transmitted without delay and replies were received both from land-based stations and ships. The master received no response to his request for medical and helicopter assistance. Both involved seamen on deck lost their lives.

SummaryOfEvents:
M/V ALAMO departed from Bahia Blanca, Argentina, on 27th May 2004 en route to Puerto Montt, Chile, with 10 officers and 18 seafarers on board, all of them with Chilean nationality. The ship entered Magellan’s Strait on 31st May 2004 at 00:54 hours. 
On  2nd June at 02:30 hours LT, as consequence of the weather deterioration, the Captain decided to look for protection and navigated the ship to the Ladrilleros Channel in order to wait for more favourable conditions. 
Later the ship entered Fallos Channel, where the Captain decided to have a beam distance of 3 cables with Punta Sequel Lighthouse, into the Adalberto Channel. Closer to the Punta Sequel Lighthouse the ship had a starboard leeway and the Captain ordered to put all helm to port; however, the ship did not react to the last order, and the Captain ordered full power ahead.
 At about 20:45 hours LT,  after a strong impact was sustained at the bow, the ship had a port listing. The captain ordered minimum speed ahead in order to evaluate the situation and to activate emergency procedures accordingly.
   The ship's condition, after verification,  was the following: grounded, with bulbous bow resting on a submerged rock at SW of the Punta Sequel Lighthouse, with bow in direction to islet Koffert.
    In order to prevent any movement of the ship towards the coast line or rocks in the vicinity as a consequence of the sea current and wind, the Captain ordered ship engine ahead slowly.
   The ship floated alone at about 21:56 hours LT as a result of the wind reduction and flood tide, at that time the Captain ordered that machines be stopped. About 22:00 hours LT with machines and helm movements the ship took distance from the grounding position. 
    No pollution was generated by this accident.
The grounding was due to mistakes made in planning the trip (lack of consideration of the sailing directions and deficient route contro)l.

SummaryOfEvents:
Narrative It was a very pleasant day, which provided the opportunity to carry out routine maintenance on board a UK flagged trawler. Some of the crew were working aft on the trawl wires, the skipper was in the wheelhouse and the chief engineer was on the main deck. The engineer noticed that the port main deck floodlight situated on the 4 metre high platform (Figure 1) between the forward masts had a "crazed" glass. This was not unusual; a combination of the hot glass and cold sea spray had caused this before, and the engineer was accustomed to changing the glass.

Having obtained a new glass, the engineer climbed the ladder to the platform. He was wearing safety shoes, but no other personal protection equipment. He was not wearing a safety harness, although six were on board and all were in date for test. The engineer informed nobody that he was going aloft.

The engineer accessed the platform through an unguarded gap in the guardrails (Figure 2). The platform (Figure 3) was wet, did not have a nonslip finish and contained several tripping hazards.

He stepped over these, knelt down and rotated the floodlight to remove the damaged glass. The next thing the engineer recalls was a helicopter hovering overhead preparing to transfer him to hospital.

From the subsequent investigation, it was clear that the glass had been replaced and that the floodlight was returned to its original position.

The engineer then either stepped back through the guardrail gap, or fell from the mast ladder onto the wheelhouse roof, landing on his back and cutting his head. No one saw him fall, although the skipper heard him land on the wheelhouse roof.

Sadly, this accident resulted in the engineer severing the lower part of his spinal cord.

The Lessons

While we cannot be sure whether the lack of a non-slip finish, or the open guardrail contributed to this accident, the following lessons should be learned from this tragic accident:

1. Safety harnesses or other restraining devices must always be used when working aloft in accordance with the Code for Safe Working Practices. There should be no exceptions to this rule.

2. Safety chains should be fitted to open accesses in guardrails. If they have to be removed to gain access, they should be re-instated immediately.

3. A non-slip finish should be applied to hazardous working deck areas, or where risk assessments have identified there is a risk to personnel.

4. When working aloft, crew should tell others of their intentions, and they should be aware of any potential hazards.

5. Risk assessments should be conducted where personnel are exposed to dangerous or unusual activities.

At 19.00 hours LT on 26 February 2004, the Bahamas-registered passenger ship ASTOR let go its mooring lines and departed the Queensland port of Townsville.

The ship, equipped with twin rudders, controllable pitch main propellers and a single bow thruster, did not require a tug for the departure. The master, as is common practice on passenger ships, manoeuvred the ship clear of the berth and then, even though this was his first visit to Townsville, kept the conduct of the ship without consulting the harbour pilot. The pilot adopted an advisory role.

As the ship was turning from the harbour into Platypus Channel, part of the approach channel to the port, it grounded on its port side. The ship heeled three degrees to starboard and, after about three minutes, slid clear of the bank without assistance and continued out of the channel.

After it had cleared the channel, the ship stopped for about two hours to check that the hull was not breached and that all machinery was operating normally. Immediately upon notification of the grounding, the Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA) placed a detention order on the ship until the ship’s classification society was satisfied that Astor was seaworthy. When it was confirmed that the hull and machinery were in proper condition the detention order was lifted and the ship then proceeded to Cairns. At Cairns, an underwater survey of the hull was carried out to ascertain the extent of any damage.

At midnight, on Sunday 15 February 2004, the ro-ro passenger vessel STENA NAUTICA sailed from Grena port, Denmark, on her regular service to Varberg on the west coast of Sweden. 
The weather was calm with intermittent fog.
At about 04.30 hrs in the morning, the course of the ferry was crossed from the port side by the smaller vessel JOANNA en route from Amsterdam to Falkenberg. As the vessels' course line crossed, JOANNA made a violent turn to starboard and collided with STENA NAUTICA.  Joanna's stem penetrated STENA NAUTICA's plating on the starboard side and tore a hole in the cargo deck space and engine rooms.
Water poured into the engine rooms and since watertight doors were open, large parts of STENA NAUTICA's engine area filled rapidly.  Her power supply and propulsion machinery were put out of action and she lay unsteerable.  The Master decided to abandon ship.
In the vicinity, there were a tugboat and another ro-ro passenger ferry.  The passengers and the majority of the crew were transferred to these and subsequently put ashore.
STENA NAUTICA was towed into port in Varberg. The work of sealing the damage and preventing her from sinking was extensive and took several days.
Nobody was injured.  The cargo including the racehorses on board was saved, but STENA NAUTICA sustained extensive damage.  She was repaired in a shipyard in Poland and returned to service in June 2004.
JOANNA was able to continue to Falkenberg after the collision, with a fairly small leak in her stem.

Location: Mediterranean Sea, 120 nm W. of Crete
Vatlestraumen, sea area S. of Bergen
SummaryOfEvents:
On the weekend of 17 and 18 January 2004, the bulk carrier ROCKNES loaded a cargo of gravel in the South Norwegian port of Eikefet, north of Bergen.  After the loading works had been completed on Sunday evening, the vessel left Eikefet shortly before 09:00h on Monday 19 January 2004, with a pilot on board and proceeded to bunker in Skalevik near Bergen, where she moored at 11:40h.  Four hours later, at about 15:40h, mv ROCKNES continued its voyage, still with a pilot on board, heading for the intended port of discharge in Emden, Germany.
At about 16:23h, mv ROCKNES changed course to port in order to enter Vatlestraumen. At about 16:27h the vessel touched ground with her starboard side in the narrow passage; immediately she developed a list to starboard that could not be stopped.  Within a few minutes mv ROCKNES capsized completely.
Twelve of the thirty persons on board could be recovered alive as a result of the rescue measures initiated immediately.  Three of them were freed from the hull of the vessel floating keel upwards after several hours.
Escaping fuel polluted Vatlestraumen and the adjacent coastline.  The Norwegian Coastal Authority collected a total of 1.291 tons of emulsified water which has been determined to be equivalent to 227,5 tons of IFO 380.
After the rescue attempts were discontinued, the vessel was towed into a bay on Agotnes.  The hull of the vessel was examined and it was decided to upright mv ROCKNES again.  From 17 March 2004 onwards work proceeded on turning the vessel; on 29 March 2004 it was lying upright again.  On 5 April 2004 mv ROCKNES was towed to the Bergen Mekaniske yard at Laksevag near Bergen.  The vessel was inspected and a decision was taken to reinstate it.  To this end mv ROCKNES was towed to Poland for repairs and modifications.  It was initially estimated that the necessary repair works would take more than one and a half years.

SummaryOfEvents:
On 15th January 2004, the trawler BUGALED BREIZH, out of Le Guilvinec, was engaged in fishing operations south of Lizard Point, Cornwall.  The weather conditions were what could be expected in the area at that time of year : a southwesterly gale was blowing, visibility was good but reduced in rain.
Another trawler out of Le Guilvinec was fishing in the same area.  The two vessels were in the habit of working the same waters and called each other frequently on VHF radio.
The BUGALED BREIZH called the other trawler twice to say that she was capsizing and to give her position, contact was then lost and the vessel went down with loss of all hands; the other fishing vessel raised the alarm.
MRCC Falmouth deployed numerous aerial and maritime rescue resources.  Of the five crew members of the BUGALED BREIZH, two bodies were found on the same day, a third body was found in the wreck when it was refloated.
Three days after the sinking, the wreck of the BUGALED BREIZH was located and filmed by the camera of an MDV from a french minesweeper; she was subsequently refloated by court order in July 2004.

On 4 January 2004 Hong Kong registered ship “Dias” was sailing from Abbot Point in Australia to the port of Taenan of South Korea with coal cargo. At around 16:35 hours as the Dias was proceeding to New Guinea Strait, the Chief Officer and the deck cadet were found collapsed inside the bilge space enclosure of No 6 cargo hold. Rescue operation by the ship’s staff was immediately carried out. At 17:40 hours both persons were pulled out from the bilge space enclosure in unconscious state and brought to the main deck. Cardioids pulmonary respiration was given to both persons but without response, no pulse was found on them.

At 19:22 hours radio medical advice was received from doctor in Australia, CPR was continued and Adrenaline injection was administered. At 20:14 hours as advised by the medical doctor, the pulse, heartbeat, reaction to light were checked  to have no response, the two persons were proclaimed dead later in the evening.

Location: Mediterranean Sea, 129kms N. of Bajaia port, Algeria

SummaryOfEvents:
The Bahamas registered chemical tanker “Panama Serena” which was built in turkey, entered service in June 2003, exploded and caught fire at Porto Torres, Sardinia in Italia on 01 January 2004. The catastrophic damage caused resulted in the vessel being declared a constructive total loss (CTL), two crew members were tragically killed and one was injured.

The “Panama Serena” had arrived at Porto Torres on 31 December 2003 with a cargo of Benzene and cut C6 (C6), the Benzene discharge had been complete and the vessel was close to completion of discharge of the C6. All cargo tanks were loaded upon arrival at Porto Torres, except No.4C which was washed, clean and dry.

At approximately 11:55 on 01 January 2004, as the cargo deck watch was changing, the vessel was shaken by the first in a series of violent explosions, which resulted in an intense fire amidships, within the cargo tank area of the vessel.

The duty 3rd Mate and relieving 2nd Mate were handing over the cargo watch in the cargo control room (CCR), which overlooked the main deck at the time of the first explosion. The seaman on duty and the seaman taking over the deck watch were outside on the main deck and were both tragically killed in the series of explosions. The Chief Mate, who was resting in his cabin at the time, was injured.

The Master and the remainder of the crew who were all within the aft accommodation area managed to escape from the vessel by jumping over the stern into the water, then climbing into the stern launch freefall lifeboat, which had automatically launched due to the extreme force of the explosions which wracked the vessel. 

The fire was eventually brought under control by the shore based emergency fire services; however they were unable to save the two seamen o the main deck or prevent extensive damage to the vessel and the terminal jetty due to the intense nature of the fire which followed the series of explosion.

Due to the catastrophic damage caused to the vessel (which can be seen in the photographs attached to this report) it has been extremely difficult to identify the exact cause of the initial explosion; however a number of possible causes were identified and are covered within this report.
Consequences1: Total loss of the ship,Loss of life
